fields.Text: Conundrum 1: Intelligent agents have {{c1::limited resources}}.
Conundrum 2: Computation is {{c1::local}}, but problems have {{c2::global constraints}}.
Conundrum 3: Logic is {{c1::deductive}}, but many problems are {{c2::abductive or inductive}}.
Conundrum 4: The world is {{c1::dynamic}}, but knowledge is {{c2::limited}}.
Conundrum: Many AI problems are {{c1::computationally intractable}}, yet require {{c2::near real-time performance}} from agents with limited resources.
fields.Extra: From Spring 2015 Final Exam - Key conundrum

fields.Text: AI problems: Knowledge often arrives {{c1::incrementally}}.
AI problems: Problems exhibit {{c1::recurring patterns}}.
AI problems: Problems have {{c1::multiple levels of granularity}}.
AI problems: Many problems are {{c1::computationally intractable}}.
AI problems: The world is {{c1::open-ended}}, but knowledge is {{c2::limited}}.
AI agents have limited {{c1::computing power}}.
AI agents have limited {{c1::sensors}}.
AI agents have limited {{c1::attention}}.
AI agents' knowledge is {{c1::incomplete}} relative to the world.
The four schools of AI are defined by two axes: {{c1::thinking vs. acting}} and {{c2::optimally vs. like humans}}.
"Agents that think optimally" includes examples like {{c1::semantic web}} and {{c2::machine learning}}.
"Agents that act optimally" includes examples like {{c1::airplane autopilots}}.
"Agents that act like humans" includes examples like {{c1::improvisational robots}}.
Cognitive systems exhibit {{c1::human-like intelligence}} through processes like learning, reasoning, and memory.
The three layers of a cognitive system are {{c1::metacognition}}, {{c2::deliberation}}, and {{c3::reaction}}.
Metacognition means {{c1::thinking about thinking}}.
Deliberation includes three components: {{c1::reasoning}}, {{c2::learning}}, and {{c3::memory}}.
Reaction provides {{c1::immediate responses}} to input without deliberation.
Raven's Progressive Matrices was written in the {{c1::1930s}} to examine {{c2::general intelligence}}.
Raven's matrices are unique because problems are strictly {{c1::visual}}.
The three types of Raven's matrix problems are {{c1::2x1}}, {{c2::2x2}}, and {{c3::3x3}}.
Principle 1: KBAI agents represent knowledge into {{c1::knowledge structures}} to guide reasoning.
Principle 2: Learning in KBAI agents is often {{c1::incremental}}.
Principle 3: Reasoning in KBAI is {{c1::top-down}} as well as {{c2::bottom-up}}.
Principle 4: KBAI agents {{c1::match methods to tasks}}.
Principle 5: KBAI agents use {{c1::heuristics}} to find solutions that are {{c2::good enough}}, not necessarily optimal.
Principle 6: KBAI agents make use of {{c1::recurring patterns}} in problems.
Principle 7: The architecture enables {{c1::reasoning}}, {{c2::learning}}, and {{c3::memory}} to support and constrain each other.
A semantic network uses {{c1::nodes}} to represent concepts and {{c2::directional links}} to represent relationships.
Semantic network components: Lexically = {{c1::nodes}}, Structurally = {{c2::directional links}}, Semantically = {{c3::application-specific labels}}.
Good representations make {{c1::relationships explicit}}.
Good representations expose {{c1::natural constraints}}.
Good representations bring {{c1::objects and relations}} together.
Good representations exclude {{c1::extraneous details}}.
Good representations should be transparent, concise, complete, {{c1::fast}}, and {{c2::computable}}.
The Guards & Prisoners problem: boat may take only {{c1::1 or 2}} people at a time.
The Guards & Prisoners problem: prisoners may never {{c1::outnumber guards}} on either coast.
The classic 3-3 Guards & Prisoners problem takes {{c1::11}} moves to solve.
Generate and test: {{c1::generate}} all possible solutions, then {{c2::test}} if they are valid.
A good generator is {{c1::complete}} (generates all solutions).
A good generator is {{c1::efficient}} (doesn't waste resources).
A good generator is {{c1::smart}} (generates likely solutions first).
A smart generator is informed by {{c1::knowledge about the problem}}.
A smart tester uses {{c1::domain knowledge}} to efficiently evaluate solutions.
Generate and Test is a {{c1::general-purpose}} method used when {{c2::knowledge-based methods}} are not available.
fields.Extra: From Spring 2015 Midterm Q7 - Fallback method

fields.Text: Means-ends analysis identifies the {{c1::difference}} between current state and {{c2::goal state}}.
Means-ends analysis prefers operators that {{c1::minimize distance}} to the goal.
A state space is the set of all {{c1::possible states}} connected by {{c2::operators}}.
Means-ends analysis can fail when the solution requires temporarily {{c1::increasing distance}} to the goal.
Problem reduction breaks a {{c1::hard problem}} into {{c2::easier subproblems}}.
A subgoal is an {{c1::intermediate state}} that must be achieved before the final goal.
A cognitive architecture defines how an agent maps {{c1::percepts}} to {{c2::actions}}.
The formula for cognitive architectures: {{c1::Architecture}} + {{c2::Content}} = {{c3::Behavior}}.
The function notation for cognitive architectures is f: {{c1::P*}} → {{c2::A}} (percepts to action).
The three levels of analysis: {{c1::Task/Knowledge}}, {{c2::Algorithm/Symbol}}, {{c3::Hardware/Implementation}}.
Task/Knowledge level example: {{c1::playing baseball}} or {{c2::selecting a pitch}}.
Algorithm/Symbol level example: {{c1::means-ends analysis}} or {{c2::semantic networks}}.
Hardware/Implementation level example: {{c1::a brain}} or {{c2::transistors}}.
SOAR has three long-term memories: {{c1::procedural}}, {{c2::semantic}}, and {{c3::episodic}}.
Procedural memory stores {{c1::how to do things}} (production rules).
Semantic memory stores {{c1::facts about the world}}.
Episodic memory stores {{c1::specific experiences}}.
Working memory holds the {{c1::current state}} and {{c2::active goals}}.
A production rule format: IF {{c1::conditions}} THEN {{c2::actions}}.
When multiple production rules match, an {{c1::impasse}} occurs.
Chunking creates a new {{c1::production rule}} from experience to resolve impasses faster.
In a production system, the working memory contents {{c1::evolve}} as rules fire and modify the state.
fields.Extra: From Fall 2014 Midterm - Show evolving working memory

fields.Text: An impasse in a production system occurs when a {{c1::rule is missing}} needed to continue reasoning.
fields.Extra: From Spring 2015 Midterm Q5 - Learning from impasses

fields.Text: When a rule is missing, a production system can learn from {{c1::cases}} to acquire the missing rule.
fields.Extra: From Fall 2014 Midterm Q2d - Learning rules from cases

fields.Text: A frame represents a {{c1::stereotyped situation}} with slots for expected information.
Frame property 1: Frames represent {{c1::stereotypes}}.
Frame property 2: Frames provide {{c1::default values}}.
Frame property 3: Frames exhibit {{c1::inheritance}}.
A frame class is a {{c1::template}} with default values.
A frame instance is a {{c1::specific example}} that may override defaults.
Frame inheritance: a frame can inherit slot values from a {{c1::parent frame}}.
Event frame format: (event ({{c1::actor}}, {{c2::object}}, {{c3::location}}, {{c4::time}}, {{c5::instrument}})).
fields.Extra: From Fall 2014 Final Q1 - Story understanding frames

fields.Text: Advantage of frames over logic: frames provide {{c1::default values}} and {{c2::inheritance}}.
fields.Extra: From Fall 2014 Midterm Q1c - Comparing representations

fields.Text: Advantage of logic over frames: logic provides {{c1::formal inference rules}} and {{c2::proof procedures}}.
fields.Extra: From Fall 2014 Midterm Q1c - Comparing representations

fields.Text: Learning by recording cases: store {{c1::problem-solution pairs}} and retrieve the most {{c2::similar}} case.
The nearest neighbor method finds the most similar case by calculating {{c1::distance}} in feature space.
k-Nearest Neighbor considers the {{c1::k closest}} cases and uses {{c2::majority voting}} or averaging.
Assumption 1 of case-based methods: {{c1::Patterns exist}} in the world.
Assumption 2 of case-based methods: {{c1::Similar problems}} have {{c2::similar solutions}}.
CBR Stage 1 - Retrieval: find a {{c1::similar case}} from memory.
CBR Stage 2 - Adaptation: {{c1::modify the solution}} for the new problem.
CBR Stage 3 - Evaluation: test if the {{c1::solution works}}.
CBR Stage 4 - Storage: store the {{c1::new case}} for future use.
Case adaptation modifies a retrieved solution to fit the {{c1::current problem's requirements}}.
A discrimination tree organizes cases by asking {{c1::questions about features}}.
CBR differs from recording cases by adding {{c1::adaptation}}, {{c2::evaluation}}, and {{c3::storage}} stages.
A case has two main components: {{c1::contents}} (problem + solution) and {{c2::indices}} (features for retrieval).
fields.Extra: From Spring 2015 Midterm Q4 - Case structure

fields.Text: Advantage of rule-based over CBR: rules provide {{c1::explicit reasoning}} that is easier to {{c2::explain}}.
fields.Extra: From Fall 2014 Midterm Q2c - Comparing methods

fields.Text: Advantage of CBR over rule-based: CBR can handle {{c1::novel situations}} by adapting {{c2::similar cases}}.
fields.Extra: From Fall 2014 Midterm Q2c - Comparing methods

fields.Text: Incremental concept learning learns concepts {{c1::one example at a time}}.
When given a positive example that doesn't fit the concept, {{c1::generalize}}.
When given a negative example that fits the concept, {{c1::specialize}}.
Variabilization converts specific {{c1::constants}} into {{c2::variables}}.
Require-link heuristic: a link {{c1::must be present}} to be a positive example.
Forbid-link heuristic: a link {{c1::must be absent}} to be a positive example.
Drop-link heuristic: a link is {{c1::not necessary}} for the concept.
Enlarge-set heuristic: {{c1::multiple objects}} may fit one role (e.g., "brick OR wedge").
Climb-tree heuristic: generalize using {{c1::background knowledge hierarchy}} (e.g., brick+wedge → block).
Close-interval heuristic: {{c1::expand the range}} of acceptable values.
In incremental concept learning, {{c1::background knowledge}} enables the climb-tree heuristic.
fields.Extra: From Spring 2015 Midterm Q6 - Using background knowledge

fields.Text: Classification maps percepts into {{c1::equivalence classes}} to reduce complexity.
Equivalence classes: groups of percepts treated {{c1::the same way}} for decision-making.
Problem: 300 percepts = 2×10^90 combinations, more than {{c1::atoms in the universe}}.
Classification reduces 2^n percepts to {{c1::k concepts}}.
Axiomatic concepts are defined by {{c1::necessary and sufficient conditions}}.
Axiomatic concept example: a circle (all points {{c1::equidistant from a center}}).
Prototype concepts are defined by a {{c1::typical example}} with {{c2::overridable properties}}.
Prototype concept example: a {{c1::chair}} with default features like 4 legs.
Exemplar concepts are defined by {{c1::implicit abstractions}} of specific instances.
Exemplar concept example: {{c1::beauty}} (defined only by examples).
Formality ranking (most to least): {{c1::Axiomatic}} → {{c2::Prototype}} → {{c3::Exemplar}}.
A concept hierarchy: specific concepts {{c1::inherit properties}} from general concepts.
Bottom-up classification starts with {{c1::percepts}} and matches to {{c2::concepts}}.
Soundness: only {{c1::valid conclusions}} can be proven.
Completeness: {{c1::all valid conclusions}} can be proven.
A predicate maps object arguments to {{c1::true or false}} values.
AND (∧): true only if {{c1::both}} operands are true.
OR (∨): true if {{c1::at least one}} operand is true.
NOT (¬): returns the {{c1::opposite}} truth value.
IMPLIES (A ⇒ B): false only when A is {{c1::true}} and B is {{c2::false}}.
A ⇒ B with A=False and B=False equals {{c1::True}}.
A ⇒ B with A=False and B=True equals {{c1::True}}.
A ⇒ B with A=True and B=True equals {{c1::True}}.
A ⇒ B with A=True and B=False equals {{c1::False}}.
Implication elimination: A ⇒ B becomes {{c1::¬A ∨ B}}.
Modus Ponens: If p ⇒ q and {{c1::p}}, then {{c2::q}}.
Modus Tollens: If p ⇒ q and {{c1::¬q}}, then {{c2::¬p}}.
Modus Ponens is also called {{c1::affirming the antecedent}}.
Modus Tollens is also called {{c1::denying the consequent}}.
De Morgan's Law: ¬(A ∧ B) ≡ {{c1::¬A ∨ ¬B}}.
De Morgan's Law: ¬(A ∨ B) ≡ {{c1::¬A ∧ ¬B}}.
Commutative property: A ∧ B ≡ {{c1::B ∧ A}}.
Distributive property: A ∧ (B ∨ C) ≡ {{c1::(A ∧ B) ∨ (A ∧ C)}}.
Associative property: A ∨ (B ∨ C) ≡ {{c1::(A ∨ B) ∨ C}}.
Universal quantifier (∀): for {{c1::all}} x, the statement is true.
Existential quantifier (∃): there exists {{c1::at least one}} x where the statement is true.
Resolution theorem proving assumes the {{c1::negation}} of the goal, then derives a {{c2::contradiction}}.
Proof by refutation: assume the {{c1::negation}} of what you want to prove.
Conjunctive Normal Form (CNF): a {{c1::conjunction (AND)}} of {{c2::disjunctions (ORs)}}.
To convert implication to CNF: 1) Use {{c1::implication elimination}}, 2) Apply {{c2::De Morgan's Law}}.
Propositional logic example: "The robot climbed the table" becomes {{c1::Climb-Up(Robot, Table)}}.
Deduction: from {{c1::general rules}} and {{c2::specific facts}}, derive a {{c3::conclusion}}.
fields.Extra: From Spring 2015 Final Q4 - Types of reasoning

fields.Text: Induction: from {{c1::specific examples}}, derive a {{c2::general rule}}.
fields.Extra: From Spring 2015 Final Q4 - Types of reasoning

fields.Text: Abduction: from {{c1::an observation}} and {{c2::a rule}}, infer the {{c3::best explanation}}.
fields.Extra: From Spring 2015 Final Q4 - Types of reasoning

fields.Text: Deduction is {{c1::truth-preserving}}; induction and abduction are {{c2::not guaranteed to be true}}.
fields.Extra: From Spring 2015 Final Q4 - Types of reasoning

fields.Text: A STRIPS operator has two parts: {{c1::preconditions}} (what must be true) and {{c2::postconditions}} (what becomes true).
fields.Extra: From Spring 2015 Midterm Q1 - STRIPS planning

fields.Text: STRIPS planning works {{c1::backward}} from goal to initial state or {{c2::forward}} from initial to goal.
fields.Extra: From Spring 2015 Midterm Q2 - STRIPS planning

fields.Text: STRIPS operator example - Climb_Up: Precondition = {{c1::Location(Robot, On_Floor)}}, Postcondition = {{c2::Location(Robot, On_Table)}}.
fields.Extra: From Spring 2015 Midterm Q1 - STRIPS example

fields.Text: Working memory in production systems can be represented using {{c1::frames}}.
Semantic networks show {{c1::relationships}}, frames organize {{c2::stereotypical knowledge}}, production rules encode {{c3::procedural knowledge}}.
Generate-and-test explores {{c1::all possibilities}}; means-ends analysis uses {{c2::distance-to-goal heuristics}}.
Bottom-up reasoning is {{c1::data-driven}} (percepts → concepts).
Top-down reasoning is {{c1::expectation-driven}} (goals → evidence).
Incremental concept learning {{c1::builds}} concepts; classification {{c2::applies}} them.
When a production system hits an impasse due to a missing rule, it can use {{c1::case-based reasoning}} to find a solution and {{c2::learn a new rule}}.
fields.Extra: From Fall 2014 Midterm Q2d - Connecting methods

fields.Text: Generate and Test is an example of a {{c1::universal method}} that can apply to most problems.
fields.Extra: From Spring 2015 Final Q3a - Universal methods

fields.Text: Multiple {{c1::specialized methods}} cooperating is often more effective than a single {{c2::universal method}}.
fields.Extra: From Spring 2015 Final Q3b - Method cooperation
